This is why internet advertising is a bubble. One that is bursting. Its a very easy formula:
Internet advertising skyrocketed into interest with Google, Myspace, Facebook and Youtube. It was a genuine value as they were "smart" and "targeted" ads, vs the previous carpet bombing of the consumers vying for attention. This increased the value of ads over the traditional method.
Then came the abuses of the ad system. Buying engagement as a way to increase your value to platforms, and in turn, to advertisers. But the engagement is fake so your increase in value is only contingent on you being in the minority, among creators that provide actual value. So "slipping through the cracks" so to speak. This falsely increased the value of platforms to advertisers. Further driving up the perceived value of Facebook, google, youtube, etc.
Then, the situation further escalated with full on "internet celebrities" appearing over night. Youtubers who were marginally popular on TikTok or other platforms, suddenly appearing into existence with millions of subscribers (clearly bought accounts).
And the biggest bombshell is the "advertising companies" themselves. They obscure and distill the real impact that their advertising real-estate has to a business.

Ultimately ads are only valuable if people buy the product. A friendly of mine owns his own company that installs window blinds. He used to pay for advertising on Facebook, google, and youtube. He has millions of hits on each platform with close to 0 real life customers resulting from that advertising. This may be statistically insignificant, but I believe its a much larger trend in the advertising space.

Facebook saw this and rebranded to Meta (rather poorly). But I believe that any company that relies on ad revenue for a main income method is in danger. The next 5-10 years are going to be very interesting.

Being from India, I had started my business page on Facebook some 3 years back, related to wedding photography.

There was a silver lining to all of it though.

My suggestion to anyone genuinely looking to promote a business in SE Asia - just promote your page to around 2k likes, so that it seems credible. And that's it.

So there's another thing I accidentally discovered. When I tried to share this video on WhatsApp from my android phone it didn't caption it (WhatsApp automatically lists the video title next to the video thumbnail) just above the typing area. I tried to confirm if this was some glitch with my phone or Internet or WhatsApp server so I tried to share some other video from YouTube immediately. Surprisingly WhatsApp captioned these videos. I tried sharing this video again and another video and repeated this multiple times but the results were still the same. So what does this tell us?

1. WhatsApp owned by Facebook which always argued for the cause of true and reliable information dissemination secretly takes a back foot when it is not in their interests.
2. Even though Whatsapp claims to be end-to-end encrypted it still knows what you are sharing and the information can be recovered even if deleted (eg: CBI in India was able to recover deleted Whatsapp chats of alleged abettors of a man's suicide)

Edit: P. S I know this is a fairly old video but I decided to write this post to make some of us think, what measures corporations take discreetly to hide things that harm their reputation, enter a market where they are unwelcomed etc

In this case it was a background Whatsapp algorithm that was fairly unknowable until I decided to share this video

Consider the country Myanmar, until recently there were no cell phones. There are no viable radio, television or newspapers for the dissemination of news. Myanmar, formerly Burma has a hard time with a repressive government and also difficulty developing. Recently I read that the repressive government had been overthrown. I thought this was great until I started reading that militant Buddhists(?) were killing people in the Muslim minority. There are many things wrong with this story that don't add up. Here is what I found. The better economy in Myanmar enabled a good number of people to obtain smart phones. What was the app that took off, almost to the exclusion of all others ~ Facebook. The people had no experience with slick media and believed it all. The government of Myanmar (army) noticed this and uses Facebook to largely manipulate what the people see. This included a hate campaign against the Muslim minority. A case of genocide facilitated by Facebook.

I invested over $35,000 in advertising on Facebook, not to mention the cost of creating the ads, hiring an analytics team, and the two years invested in building a marketing strategy around Facebook’s platform. Here’s my experience so far, and I hope to find others who might have had a similar one.

The “brand” for my business is one based on authenticity. Political correctness would, therefore, conflict with our commitment to be genuine. We’re not apologetic whenever we happen to cross fashionable boundaries set by cultural norms. We don’t aim to provoke, but neither do we aim to miss for the sake of avoiding injury to snowflakes. Even if that means we alienate a large segment of our potential market, it’s a calculated risk to be authentic.

Turns out many of the snowflakes are at Facebook, who can have a direct impact on our results. Something we hadn’t calculated. We expected the market to decide how marketable is our brand and product, not Facebook gatekeepers.

Notwithstanding outstanding metrics, we’ve seen too many anomalies that wouldn’t happen in an environment of statistical probabilities. Too many things that have had material impact on our marketing results to chalk-up to coincidence or error.

I’ll spare the details, but Facebook employees with too many discretionary privileges exposes the company to potential fraud. They can manipulate results of advertising dollars that should, otherwise, be determined by market forces only.

Completely accurate. I have a Facebook page for my video editing projects, I post a video rather infrequently, it is more just a place to keep a backlog of effects I played with and whatnot. And to be honest, not even my own friends follow that page. I never paid for advertising or anything. But I do end up having a ton of followers of the page originating from what you would describe as click farm activity. In that there has been a steady trickle of random people who like my page, but the view count on the videos never goes up (videos auto play when you scroll over them on FB, so I take this as a sign of absolute zero engagement). It had always weirded me out a little. My page has like 200 random people that have liked it, but a three year old video still has 13 views.... Seems my page has been used as a supurfluous "like dumpster" for folks who need to randomize their online activity to avoid being called out for click farming. Thanks for solving that mystery.

On a slightly more judgemental(?) Note, isn't it interesting that in lieu of actual engagement. A good way FB could combat click-farms would be to limit the number of likes to a reasonable average that a user is likely to use per day.

Its like fighting email spamming by adding a tarpit, where you deliberately limit the response time a little bit, so that it has little impact on real email users, but hits hard on bulk spammers.

Limiting the number of likes a user can give to a reasonable number, would not impact the users much( if anything, it would make their likes more meaningful ) but it would hit hard on click farms. They would spend their daily quota in minutes.

Sadly we have pretty much the same experience with Facebook. We are advertising for a few years and building a significant amount of experience. We have discussed campaigns with other advertisers and compared 'call-to-action' metrics. The consensus is that advertising on Facebook does not get results in terms of any call to action besides "Likes" which we suspect Facebook manipulates.

We have run a few experiments by abruptly ceasing advertising, placing our own tracker on the page and noticed that we accumulated a greater number of "unlikes" than visits to the page. As soon as we restarted the advertising campaigns, even small ones, the bleeding of likes stopped. The likes increased, even greater than hits to the page if we surged the advertising. We just recently made a decision to place our advertising dollars elsewhere.

We are a genuine NGO non-profit and are always strapped for cash as the cost of medicine and health care instruments climb through the roof.

We know Facebook ripped us off and cannot afford to have that happen; concomitantly we have a a fiduciary responsibility to our stakeholders not to deal with corporations that apply unscrupulous practices to their money-making antics.

The Facebook promises of "reach" are absolute nonsense. Compared to TV, Radio and Print there is no governing authority and no board of measurement that has any credibility to verify advertising cost per thousands. It's smoke and mirrors.

Facebook is extremely restrictive about advertising content because it has only contributor content as an asset. But sometimes the restrictions are absurd. There is no functioning redress for any problem.

We contemplate seeking out class-mates and bringing a class action suit against these rogue gangsters who have absolutely no conscience and no commitment to customer care. Our goal would be to recover all funds expended or those for which Facebook cannot offer a proof-of-performance.

There are other facets of our experience with Facebook which have been documented in Wikipedia with respect to Face book’s' "rape pages “and child exploitation policies. We won't go into that here but our knowledge of dealing face-to-face with executives of this company has an alarming tinge. .

Another issue that occurs is when you pay for likes from facebook, they're going to promote your page in front of those likely to like something, because after all they've promised an approximate amount of likes to dollars. So they won't only target a specific audience but a subset within that audience that is most likely to click. This just creates a feedback loop increasing the ratio of fake likes to real likes each time you pay for promotion. So it's not just forcing you to pay twice, but instead exponentially to get to your intended audience as each payment also increases the problem it's trying to solve. It may be a linear relationship, but you get the point. Facebook is ultimately a scam.

Advertising on facebook makes ennormous (dont know if I spell it correctly) amounts of money. Its not like its a slot machine where you put 10 bucks and hope for the best, this way you are going to bankrupt real fast. What needs to be done is very in-depth research of your audience. 2000 likes might be a huge audience if they are laser targeted. On the other hand if you have 1 million likes but all are fake even if you give away something for free, no one will click on that post/like it/share it/etc.

From my not so big experience in facebook ads, ive got pretty amazing results with eCPM. The more traffic your ad brings to your website, the cheaper it gets thus bringing extra traffic for the same amount of money. What matters here is your target audience and your actual advertisment.

With all that being said and Facebook being the nice guy there is plenty of room for many peole to make good money, well, not so fast. People with big pockets will pay enough so you can NOT be their competition INCLUDING, clicking your ads, so your poor campaign goes off and the cpc/cpm/eCPM goes lower cause of lower competition.

There are existing bot farms for this, there are also bot farms for ads spying. If you are/were interested in facebook advertisments you would know this.

I know this is old, but it's the first time I see this vid. The graph shown around the 4th minute is quite consistent with Zipf's Law, that states that around 20% of the product will stand for about 80% of the result.

About 20% of your followers produce about 80% of the interactions. The fact that the majority of your followers are outside of the zones that frequently speak English might contribute to them not being as interactive, but that does not mean they are false likes.

However, it does look very suspicious when you put it like that, since they obviously interacted when they liked the page.

These are my points:

1) Never pay for Likes
2) Never pay Facebook for Likes
3) Never pay others for Likes
4) Pay to reach a specific target audience.
5) Pick a goal
    a)   Conversion
    b)   Visitors
6) Your content should be engaging if your goal is to gain Likes
7) You can pay to boost posts as long as you do #4 and #6

Hello!..From Bangladesh!

As a person from Dhaka, Bangladesh and also a member of the most Facebook-using age group, I have seen that people literally like anything they see! I don't know what the logic behind this is, but one assumption is that there is no way to follow a page. What if you don't really like Audi but still want to get the updates? What if you are a die hard Apple fanboy but still want to know what's up with Microsoft?

On another note, most of the people here accept friend requests from entirely unknown people. This is actually a pretty common thing, resulting most of the Facebook accounts here having friends from 400 to 4000. Not all these accounts are fake, mind it. I am studying at a reputed private university, and I have classmates from who have thousands of friends and followers on Facebook. I myself have roughly 1000 friends on Facebook, but I have worked in different organizations for the last few years, so I can say most of the friends are genuine people wanting to connect with me, and vice versa. How is this information related to unbelievable amount of likes in pages?

The more friend you have on Facebook, the more random page suggestions and posts you get in your news feed. And since people here are usually curious to keep connection with varied range of stuff, most of them end up hitting the like buttons of those pages. This can never indicate they honestly like the pages. Facebook doesn't have any problem with this trend though, because this mechanism only gets them more and more views of posts and pages.

I felt compelled to provide an explanation, if you can call my comment one, because I have never met a single person who actually does this $1 per 1k like sort of business. It's true sometimes these people spam on public groups, and I even got spam messages from unknown Bangladeshi people to like some page. But I never met anyone from my social sphere who actually does this sort of business. So it's kind of hard to believe this, though it statistics don't seem to care about belief.

I recently paid for Facebook Ads for my page and the likes certainly went flying up. I am extremely dubious about Facebook and their paid Ad services so only invested a small amount of money to see what would happen but with the ultimate aim of getting some traffic and rego's into my website. It's obvious that from my 1000's of new likes none of them are genuine. I also paid for some 'website promotion'. Facebook is a joke, and I feel like Veritasium finally explained it similarly to the way I would.

Facebook has a major problem; the lack of a "dislike" button. I know that sounds like me being a typical internet prick, but hear me out.

These paid likes would become blatantly clear if we also had a dislike button, especially if we also have a graph of likes and dislikes over time. Did someone go from 200 likes and 10 dislikes to 20000 likes and 20 dislikes? They cheated.

You can actually see the impact a dislike button would have already; it's right here on YouTube. Take a look at any video that tells you to like it at the end, and compare it to a video that does not (optimally, two videos with similar view counts). Chances are you'll find a noticeable difference in the percent of likes. Typically, a larger percentage of views are also likes, and the ratio of likes to dislikes is around 100:1, for a "like me" video. On the other hand, a tiny percentage of views are likes for the others, with more like a 50:1 like to dislike ratio (assuming a decent video). The reason for this is simple; the "sheeple" are being asked to do something, and obeying.

The same holds true for facebook; I can't tell you how sick I am of seeing the words "Like us on facebook!" everywhere I turn. It essentially means the like counter is nothing more than a counter of how much they advertise.

Facebook's little dirty secret is revealed here. Basically most marketing on Facebook involves some level of fraudulent likes. I firmly believe that Facebook is behind mess and encourages it. The ironic thing is that we were trapped in this as well. About three years ago we embarked on a paid Facebook campaign to increase our likes. Within a very short period of time we went from 14,000 legitimate likes to over 49,000 lights. We had no idea at the time that a large portion of those likes were from Third World countries with no clear reason to like our page. It did not make sense to us why those people we go out of their way to like her page. There was clearly no financial motivation for them or so we thought. We hired someone to do this for us who apparently was unaware of this issue. Unfortunately, to this day, we are hunted by this. we have even asked FaceBook specifically to help us remove the clearly fraudulent likes, those from Third World countries that have never engage with our website or our Facebook page. However, Facebook refuses to remove these fraudulent likes even upon our request. I would much rather have a few were legitimate people that were active on our Facebook fan page rather than tens of thousands of fake people that cannot be removed. Please help us do something about this by posting your thoughts and concerns regarding this particular issue here and elsewhere. This video has already received over 3 million views.

And just in case you think it would be impossible for Facebook to fix this, he's given two very easy methods they could use to nearly eliminate the problem.

1. Devalue the likes from people that have a large, large number of them.
2. In deciding who to send content to, devalue the people who are less engaged and/or those with a lot of likes.

This works both for legitimate and illegitimate users. If someone has legitimately liked a lot of pages, they will not want to be overwhelmed with content. And if someone has liked you but isn't engaging with you, chances are they don't really want the content as much, either.

This would handle both issues. And it would actually be better for Facebook, as advertisers would start to see more bang for their buck from likes, and thus value them more. That's precisely why YouTube protects against fraudulent views.

Hahaha! I had same results; I created FB page for my company (hope you don't mind a bit of advertisement: https://www.facebook.com/DD3Dstudio), and have payed to FB for advertisement of my page... and soon, I did get likes; almost 50 in one day. And I have targeted only US and UK, and only people who like architecture, 3d modeling and CGI. But, on closer inspection of those people who liked my page, I realized that they have on average 10 000 liked stuff!!! And among those 10 000, there is most likely some stuff related to things I pointed as targeted "likes".
And I was at first, under impression that Facebook it self is basically using like farms (it's not that hard to create FB account as US or UK guy, even if you are from Egypt), but that's not the case; problem is in Facebooks faulty system! 
In theory, system looks fine; your advertisement is shown only to people that fall in to category you have selected, so it's not shown to random people, and in term, you get better chance of getting good result out of your campaign. But, problem is that Facebook system uses previous likes to determent who to show your advertisement! That way "like farmers" how have even 50 000 + likes "harvest" all of those advertisement, because they fall in to every single category (and more of them at same time).
I think that Facebook should base his display of advertisement based not on likes, but on engagement; it should take in consideration what you have shared, what likes you have clicked and stuff like that. That would in my opinion, produce more "real" likes than current system.

Allow me, if I may, to be a bit contrarian the consensus here. First, I understand that Veritasium focuses on science videos. Well, the first thing I learned in each of my science classes was that in order for an experiment to have merit there must be a control group - clearly absent here. 

Secondly, why target countries like India then complain that a bunch of likes came from India? If you don't want likes from India, etc. then don't select those countries. But more importantly, when Mr. Muller shows us his likes he received graphed against engagement amongst his fans, he seems to misunderstand is the purpose of the News Feed Algorithm. 

Mr. Muller only briefly explains how the algorithm works, but he doesn't explain why it is a function of FB. Engagement at times has very little to do with the amount of fans a page has. Because unlike most marketing platforms, FB reach doesn't come from the quantity of your followers, (opposite of an email distribution list). Instead FB reach is derived from the quality of what you are posting. Content is the distribution that is driven by the context of the conversation; A post in America will be received/viewed differently from a post in India because the context is different. That is the most important thing to understand when marketing on Facebook. 

Further, regarding the status he posted on the cat page he created: no wonder he didn't get any engagement -- the post wasn't very engaging!! I see this all the time. Posts that compel engagement ask questions, include multi-media, are thought provoking, and draw emotions so that people want to share it with their friends (thus expanding reach beyond the fans of the page). All of this is overlooked in the video. 

No disrespect to Mr. Muller - his YouTube presence is impressive, but he his making big conclusions based on a limited scope of understanding. Full disclosure: I work in social media marketing. And no, I don't work for Facebook.

This is nothing new, and essentially dates back to the early days of the internet. Search engines (even today) would allow people list their sites for trawling. Facebook is no different, I tried advertising some years ago, and found that my daily budget was consumed very quickly but did not generate any engagement or increase in sales. The only real winner was facebook who tried to encourage me to spend more money to generate more "potential" customers. I'm actually seeing this right now with my own business. 
My friend shared my page this morning.
Scrolled through their timeline and everything that they post (no matter what) ends up getting 30-40 likes within a few hours. Whether it be a silly "good morning" or some news update.

But...they shared my page about 4 hours ago. The post has received one like. According to their previous trends of people reacting to their posts, that share should have definitely received more likes than that :P...which means either the post is hidden from a lot of their friends feeds, because it is a business page, orrrr I unknowingly pissed off hundreds of people that I don't even know and have never even met before and they just refuse to like it. 

A few weeks ago, I experimented with the page promotion. Ran a post boost on one of my more informative posts for one week as well as a page promotion for one week. 
Surprise, surprise. Over the course of that one week I got ~140 likes on my page, and that post that I boosted "reached" over 18,000 people (when normally my posts only reach about 40-50 people).

Facebook...why you do this? Why not let businesses just honestly grow instead of having to buy fake likes.

I like your video very much. I have the same experience and decided to confront Facebook with this. Here is what they answered to me: "Hi,

Thanks for reaching out. We’ve looked into the claims made by the video and do not agree with the purported conclusions that were drawn.

Our company and the people and businesses on our platform do not benefit from fake likes or fake accounts. We work hard to maintain an ads experience focused on driving results against real business objectives — results which would not be possible from fake likes.

For additional context, I'm happy to address some of the claims stated in the video:

• The example of the Veritasium Page is nearly two years old. We've always focused on maintaining the integrity of our site, and have continued to place increasing focus on abuse from fake accounts. We've built a combination of automated and manual systems to block accounts used for fraudulent purposes and Like button clicks. We also take action against sellers of fake clicks and help shut them down.

• The video makes assumptions about people from international countries who have liked the Veritasium Page. We have seen that many people in many developing countries like a lot of things on Facebook. There are numerous cultural reasons why this may be, but it does not mean that they are fake accounts. As we continue to iterate, we encourage you to use our robust targeting capabilities to reach the right people who matter to your business. Our ads interfaces allow you to target the right audience for your business based on country, interests, and other demographic or behavioral factors and we never recommend that you target the entire world if it doesn’t makes sense for your business.

• We encourage you to post high quality, engaging content that correlates with your business objectives, targeted to the most relevant audience. While we also provide the option to pay for reach if relevant to your business objectives, earned and owned media is only part of the overall marketing opportunity for your business on Facebook.

We are constantly improving our systems for the benefit of people and marketing alike, and believe that we offer a powerful platform that drives significant business results – today more than ever before – and know this is possible through the power of authentic people who are active on Facebook daily. We encourage you to reach all of the people on Facebook that matter to your brand to ultimately drive your business objectives.

Please let me know if you have any additional questions.

Thanks,

Meg
Global Marketing Solutions
Facebook"

Another thought about the mass effect of social media:  I was completely WRONG in my last post.  Facebook's new algorithm is too new to have the effect that I described in the last part.  I was thinking aloud when I wrote it.

But this made me wonder further: What is the effect of being wrong in any public media?  Fifteen years ago, I may have explored thoughts in a notebook, with my girlfriend, or in a bar.  If I was wrong about something, it would be easier to admit and move on.  (also, it would be required with the girlfriend)  But social media allows me to broadcast my thoughts to a wide audience while they are happening.  Although it's likely that less than five people will read this comment, it is now public record on a page that reaches millions.  What is the psychological effect of that?

Jurors aren't allowed to discuss their decisions on a court case until after the deliberation is over.  Studies have shown that if a juror announces an early hunch, they are much more likely to try to fit the facts of the case to back up their hunch, and are harder to be swayed from the gut decision.

Social media allows & encourages us to announce our gut decisions as soon as they happen.  Have we become a society of people more likely to fit all of the news to back up our hunches?  That might be a better explanation of why so many of us have blazed off into the realm of magical thinking.

Thank you to the four of you who read this comment.

Excellent video, but Facebook's corporate focus on monetization has created several other problems not fully explored in this video:

-- Page formats are constantly changed - probably to improve promotion of paying customers.  But the changes are almost always unpopular and confuse users.

-- 3rd parties that develop applications that use Facebook routinely find themselves shut out when Facebook decides that they can make money with a similar application.  This makes development of Facebook apps a very risky business and discourages innovation on the site.

-- Facebook has absolutely no customer service.  Running a customer service center for so many users would be a significant expense, and Facebook has gotten around that expense by completely opting out. Every known method of contacting them returns an automated pointer to their help page.  And judging from complaints on other sites, there are many serious problems that people & businesses experience that require further assistance.

-- Probably the most interesting - and the scariest - thing is the possible societal effects of the 'echo chamber' Facebook's sharing strategy sets up.  While the internet allows for microcultures of thought to grow, Facebook goes further by enforcing them by algorithm, and filtering out any opposing information.  The past 10 years have seen an explosion of movements that not only unite around a common cause, but are also completely uncompromising-to-deaf with respect to any other views.  Not just to opposing views, but to any views that aren't lock-step with the main views of the movement.  These movements include: the Tea Party in the USA, the anti-vaccine movement, homeschoolers, militant vegans, climate change denial, the Egyptian government, both sides of the Ukranian conflict, anti-GMO activism, etc.  These movements disregard and disbelieve what are sometimes indisputable facts based in science, history, economic reality, etc, and sometimes enter a realm of 'magical thinking'. Are these ideas/groups/movements more disconnected from reality because so many participants are filtered from hearing other viewpoints?  It may sound crazy, but considering Facebook's reach, the filtering might just be a serious factor that's changing our world.

Derek, if you ever consider doing another follow-up video, I'd love to see these topics explored further.

Sorry but the "evidence" that Facebook is getting you fake likes is just not accurate. You can't target people in other countries with your ad and expect not to get likes from there. So what, he targeted ads to the US, UK, India, etc. Who clicks on your ad is based on multiple factors, including copy, imagery and targeting. People from these click farm countries like India are extremely likely to click on any ad to like a page that they see in their newsfeed. People from the US are more skeptical and won't just click on anything. I'd be much more interested if this "study" targeted only to the US and UK and the likes were mostly from India. This is just extremely flawed IMO. I am highly experienced running all variations of Facebook ads and have no issues with "fake likes" or likes that aren't relevant to my business. If you have no idea what you're doing when you're attempting to run Facebook ads, it's very likely that you won't get the results that you desire. I've seen such poor ads being run on Facebook, so I'm not surprised that people complain that they don't work. Of course they don't! Your image sucks, your copy sucks and your targeting is completely off.

Not only that, also understand how developing and underdeveloped countries interact differently online. I had a friend in Thailand who had liked Budweiser and Guinness FB pages, and I asked her if she knew what they were.  She said no.  I was like WTF, then why would you like their page?  She basically didn't know, but the truth was that if a picture is attractive or interesting to her, she'll click like, regardless what it says.  I've found this kind of engagement very common throughout friends who are from countries like this.  While I don't doubt there is a significant FB spam, a lot of users in developing countries will click like if there is a cute cat or a young white man, regardless of what the page is about.

Not necessarily all people who likes a lot off stuffs are from click farms.

People would simply "like" a stuff for no particular reason too. I think this is because there's simply no consequence in liking something. And all they need to do is click.
Plus, someone's value of a "like" is unique. A like might mean: "I like and support you", or "I like one of your post, so just in case...", or maybe "I'm bored". Who knows what the purpose of a like is.

But even though you like a page sincerely, you don't necessarily interact with all of them. There's simply not enough time for that. Or simply people couldn't care about all of them enough.

----- ----- -----

I think a possible way of solving this whole like problem might be "auto like removal" sort of thing. Where if you don't interact with a page for a certain time (maybe like a few months) Facebook can prompt you for permission to unlike it. And if you don't respond to that prompt, it would simply unlike for you.

It would eventually start to annoy people, especially those who likes everything. This would be good in it's own way, as it would now add a consequence of a sort to liking a page. So people would be influenced into liking only the things they actually like. And those "click farms" would have a new problem to deal with.

And for those who likes too much to follow everything, it would (hopefully) remind them, maybe the value of a like. So that they would streamline down their own likes to those they are truly interested in.

Plus, it would also remove likes from all the "dead" accounts. Although they might have to make something for actual dead people though. :/

While your overall hypothesis still holds, we did a study in India and found that there's a huge segment of genuine Facebook users (mostly teens and young adults 17-21) who like a lot of pages on Facebook and don't necessarily care very much to interact with them post that.

This has to do with the fact that a lot of people (As many as 75% of the youth in India...) access Facebook from their mobiles and use it primarily as a notification center. The reason that a lot of interaction doesn't happen here is because most kids / young adults are still on 2G connections and data is a huge concern. 

As part of a study done here in Bombay, India with a certain sample, the kids were the happiest when placed in a room with free wifi on a good connection. The interaction levels with all sorts of content went up in general.

However, the only stuff they really care to interact with must be very "cool" and "funny" and any content that happens to come on to their walls that their friends have liked, shared and commented on. 

While the definition of "cool" and "funny" is subjective to culture, age, etc... it did give us an insight in to the fact that Likes are not to be taken that seriously, interaction and engagement rates are probably the metrics that matter far more and therefore, people should ideally be charged basis that.

Oh yeah, one other thing...
Aside from the fact that Facebook is a dilution scam...

The companies that claim they're using other people to give customers views, likes, etc. are actually just using proxy bots and people who fill in captchas and do other things the bots can't do.

Proxy bots have been around for decades and are the reason certain people (like Pewdiepie) become popular.

Most of this "fraud likes" are driven by the political turmoil in Egypt since the revolution.Muslim Brotherhood are well known in Egypt that they are operating an internet groups for their political propaganda and all of their pages bought fraud likes and ads to reach out and give the illusion about how much support they have to set the trends and lead the public opinion.

I hate sounding like "I told you so..." but I've been telling people for years NOT to waste time on the Fakebook. Thanks, yet again, @Veritasium for putting more reasons why this is true in front of us with solid proof.

Facebook is a shell for a dilution scam.  This was made apparent when Zuckerberg took profits that SHOULD have been reserved for paying taxes.  He then printed more shares to cover the debt.  This devalues the stock.

In essence, he didn't want to pay the taxes and told the shareholders that they'll be paying for it.

A LEGITIMATE company takes the tax money they will eventually owe and sticks it in an interest-bearing account.  When tax week comes, they have the tax money and a little extra revenue from the interest-bearing account.

The only reason to do what facebook did, instead, is if the company doesn't think their stock is worth the price per share and wants to pass the debt down to the shareholders, whom they think overpaid for the stock.

When a penny stock does this, everyone cries foul.  But it's okay if a Nasdaq does it?  Not in my opinion.  Looks like dilution to me.

Fake Likes are a huge problem on Facebook. 

I have a FB page with about 5K fans. 2 years ago, my engagement was great. I would post great content, friends and fans would like and comment. When FB changed their algorithm to go after sponsored posting, initially I was OK with it. I felt like I had gotten free engagment for a long time and understood that they needed to make money. 

However, I experienced the same thing as presented in this video. I was getting more "likes" but no more engagement. When I sponsored a post, the "likes" I got on the post itself were not my usual engagers... they seemed to be fake accounts. When I restricted my sponsored post to target my audience, the very same thing happened. This is a no win situation for small businesses. 

Will you still get lots of engagement if you are a huge brand or celebrity.. probably people will be seeking your information more... but it is not the same viral quality that we knew in the past. 

This is a MAJOR reason I switched to #googleplus  a year and a half ago. And I do not regret it one bit.... But, I would do the same WITH G+ if they move to this model. You can not rely on any social network totally for your social engagement... realize that things change, audiences change... keep moving with the river of progress and you will be OK.

I used a free $50 worth of advertising coupon from Facebook and another free $50 coupon code that came with my website purchase.  My budget was $5 a day (which was not an option on the menu~I manually put $5 in) I only advertised on weekends, mainly Holiday weekends, when I knew more people were likely to be on Facebook.I was careful about what time my ad started and made sure to put many really good posts on my page during advertising. I got approximately half my likes that way. (4500ish) I no longer advertise so the only time my likes go up on my page is when I am posting back to back interesting posts. I have actually gotten about the same amount of likes this way, just took longer. I will not pay $ out of my pocket to advertise because I don't think its worth it. I am not making $ from my page so it doesn't make sense to spend $ for ads. Oddly enough though many people have asked if I sell plants or seeds online. I have had others offer me free assistance to help me monetize my page. I also get sent free products, seeds etc. I have met some very interesting people. But with all that said I won't spend $ on ads cuz it feels like buying likes that may or may not be interested in what I have to share. When people Like my page when I am not advertising I take it that they want to be there because their interested and no other reason. This video raises a LOT of interesting questions.
Sadly, to get traffic to your website or social media platform, you need to pay for it.. and Google has been upfront will manually manipulating their algorithm to ensure small businesses and internet marketers don't get their sites to rank in the SERPs.

That said, I use facebook advertising extensively, and my results are parallel to what Veritasium is experiencing.

I'm not condoning what facebook is doing... all I'm saying is, there's always a work-around to situations such as the one illuminated in the video above.

Consider custom audiences for instance? What is a custom audience I hear you ask?
It's a segment of the facebook users you target using facebook's graph search, thereby narrowing down on the specific customer you'd like to target.

i.e if you want to promote your weight loss product to facebook users who love McDonalds, ice cream and perhaps something else savory... you don't have to use this variables as "or" as you would in the ad editor... instead, you would search for fb users using the "and" parameter, then use software to "scrape" these users' UiDs, then run advertising campaigns that way.

How do I know whether this works?
Because the leads captured and revenue I'm generating far exceed the amount I'm paying to advertise.

In short, use facebook's graph search and software to scrape user ids, then advertise to only those, not blindly run campaigns hoping your target audience will bite.

I empathize with you, though I think it might be typical for English speaking countries. I give an example: I'm helping my friend with a page for his small business (car accessories, HID lamps, parking kits).

The ads I put targeted people from 18 and older (even though my assumption is 18-25), men and women (even though men will be more likely to buy), from Algeria (my country, even though Algiers is our city and it's a local business), didn't restrict language (even though most people use French)..

The results of this even with such a shot-gun wide ad ? 3,000 likes in just few days. Demographics ? Mostly 18-24. Mostly men. Mostly in Algiers. Mostly speaking French.

A post had 90,000 reach (2% organic). 429 likes. 75 comments. 27 shares.
Other posts have had significantly increased reach (even though not boosted), a lot of comments and a lot of shares.

It's taking time answering all the questions, and clients are coming in.

So my point being that it worked and I think it's easier because the page is in French and most crap bot-nets and like farms are more targeted and tweaked to the English side of the internet.

I have several pages, some in English and some in French.. And all the crap likes go to English pages (almost exclusively from Pakistan and India). I don't have many likes from the U.S and other countries, yet the only relevant technical comments come from Europe and the U.S.

So... You might switch the language of your page (?), without switching the language of your communication.. Or heck, switch to German. It'll certainly make our Austrian friends happy !

6:51  I have a partial explanation for you - Contesting.  Companies put out facebook contests online.  People join in, 'like' their page, add their facebook app,etc.  Of course everyone is just doing this for the prize, and it's generating a lot of disingenuous 'likes' for the company - but to those companies, this is just a numbers game to reach their specific end.  There are websites that list the current contests online in North American, one of which is contestgirl.com.  Type Facebook in their search bar and you will see a listing of contests going on facebook.  That particular website is not run by a huge corporation, but a private (and very nice) individual who has a love of contesting.  The site simply collates the online contests in a manageable way that simplifies entering contests and acts as a sort of forum for contesters.

I've had a similarly strange experience with FB ads.  My artist page only has a small number of likes, mainly family, friends of friends etc and i wanted to expand my audience so i paid £30 for an advert to run over a weekend and only targeted the U.S, Australia and Japan.  After the weekend campaign finished, i only gained 7 likes, only 1 was from Japan (apparently it appears they no longer like Anime art!) and none from the U.S or Aus!
Then to add insult to injury a week later i noticed my likes had dropped by around 15 people.  On further investigation i discovered that FB for some unknown reason had just removed a bunch of people from my page without my or their knowledge, some of those were family members including my own mother!

I have concluded that in future, instead of giving money to FB, i will instead offer that amount as a cash prize to any one of my existing followers who manages to get the most people they know to like my page...i'm willing to bet i'll get a larger and more engaging number of likes that way!

It seems like an easy enough thing to bypass... About a year ago, I made it a point to go through all of my 'likes' and friends and move them into sub-groups... high school, college, work, family, a large 'all friends' group, etc... as well topic-types based upon my 'likes' (movies, music, restaurants, etc) most importantly, removed ALL of them from my newsfeed.  Facebook hated this, and cluttered my newsfeed anyway, but, with everything in subgroups, i could focus specifically on what I wanted to focus on. I even created a subgroup called ALL, as well, again, All Friend, and All Likes... where I separated the two. Their algorithm still adjusts this, but no where near as much as it does on the newsfeed... and there's no cross-bleed, or at least drastically less. Sure it takes more time, but it also allows focus to be maintained on topic-type. Certainly took a while though, gotta confess... but it also allows me to post things to friend-types that I want to vs everyone seeing everything that I post... a lot more easily anyway.

I had a video up, promoted the link to it on Facebook through their 'legit' service, and the views rolled in on youtube. Two weeks, and 35,000 views later, youtube pulled my video down, claiming i had purchased "non-human" traffic. They refused to discuss it with me, and finally relented only the allowance to reupload the videos, even though all of the true views were all removed as well. I didn't purchase this kind of traffic, as i didn't even know it existed at the time, but now, i realize the Facebook link must be the cause! Though not a huge fan of facebook, this guy's claims are unfounded since:

1,) Likes do not represent anything as people like anything even if they don't know what they are liking, People think by liking as much as possible that it will increase their visibility.

2.) People can control the visibility of their likes from their feed without you knowing. This makes page likes practically moot.

3.) To get likes, buying them from anyone, including FB, is a waste of money. As quality of content and content shared is what attracts likes. That's the same with most informational content oriented sites.

4.) FB has something called 'Terms'. He must have forgotten.

5.) This guy like many takes what happens and is written from a literal sense on FB. The site uses sophisticated server side and page scripting code, however, it cannot fully determine things like fake pages, misinformation, disinformation or lack of information.

Lastly, his Subscribers and other related stats are very high. Which would make one wonder why bother with all the hubris. Except to garner more views or likes...his method is effective, however, the facebook claims lack merit. Good idea to returning to science videos. Veritasium, I like you.  But you know what, I also deliberately unfollowed you.  Not because you have done anything to offend me, mind you.  I unfollowed you because I use facebook to keep up with my friends, and you're not my friend.  You're a content producer, and I'm just not interested in seeing your content unless I'm actively seeking it out.  You see, my like is a vote of confidence, but just because I like someone doesn't mean that I want to engage with what they produce - if I did, I wouldn't have any time to myself - I'd spend 24 hours a day submerged in content from some 200+ producers and corporations that I "like".  But I can't do that - no one can.  I guess what I'm trying to say is that, even a genuine, unpaid like from an interested person in your target demographic is largely worthless.  You have some awesome high-quality videos!  It's more than most of my friends produce.  But that doesn't grant you the same space on my radar I reserve for friends.  I can't come over to your house and vent about the shitty day I had or the girl who stood me up or my roommate troubles - I can't invite you over for that board game or dinner and exchange stories.  You won't be there to pick me up from the airport and I won't be there to help you move.  I can understand that you must be frustrated with the means available to you to reach and engage with an audience, but I have a hard time feeling equally concerned.  The fact that I gave you a like at all - or the 1% of my daily attention span it took to consider typing all this out is something I don't give most people.  I have a hard time feeling sympathy for your lament, but it's a challenging predicament because we are all good people, I see the beauty in you and what you do, and yet here we are, unable to make time for everyone who deserves it.

This video is based on irrelevant data from 2012. You're practicing horrible targeting. You didn't even mention who you targeted. Broad or specific? Did you create a custom audience? Did you retarget your website visitors? Your email mailing list subscribers? In other words did you target RELEVANT fans?

Oh wait, these things didn't exist in 2012. Things have changed tremendously.

The people who suggest you are using Science to test this theory obviously aren't scientist. Scientist run extensive, exhaustive, testing before coming to a conclusion.

You spent $25. The Virtual Bagel Experiment was also broadly targeted to 112 million people in the very countries known for click farms. In the actual experiment almost no one from the UK and the United States liked the page.

Which would indicate the likes coming from the two countries are legit.

The virtual cat example uses a puny $25 to test. Just over 200 likes is not enough data to support your argument.

Your entire argument is weak.

Last but not least, Facebook's advertising platform has changed (for the better) 1,000 times since 2012. You have a lot more options to target your market, that is YOUR EXACT market, like your email list subscribers and website visitors.

The only thing you did here was create a viral video that is well presented as if you really did a lot of study into this issue. Which obviously you didn't.

Did you target the language?  I've found that even though you target the U.S. or an English speaking country a best practice is to make sure to target the language of the audience you wish to engage to avoid getting your page shown to people who work for click farms in other countries.  I believe that in their about me section they say they are from New York, or another city in the U.S. but their language of preference is usually their own. I don't believe Facebook is doing this...it's just people running ad campaigns and not targeting appropriately or watching their campaigns closely.  If you see poor quality likes coming in, there is a pause button to halt your campaign.

Thanks for taking the time to post your findings.  I believe that they are a bit skewed for 2 reasons:

1.  Just because a person "Likes" your page, paid or not, does not guarantee a continuous relationship of engagement with that user/paid fan.

2.  Your sample is too small.  Even the BBC demonstration of 4,000 "Likes" is not enough to form a successful claim for fraud.

Over years of marketing and paying close attention to "hot buttons" of various topics that are trending socially, it is damn hard to be batting a .333% (to use a baseball analogy) consecutively.  You do demonstrate a suspicious pattern, but also you haven't demonstrated how you have or the BBC guy engaged these people.  I'd like for you to demonstrate further by showing a sampling of what you're posting and how you are "engaging" your fans.

Here is a list of other factors to consider when trying to prove the assumption of "Facebook click fraud".

1.  You cannot predetermine someone's motive for liking something.
2.  Most people on Facebook will like something without even reading it, only following the trend of others in their friend list on liking something.
3.  The motivation to boost their position on sites like Klout and Kred.
4.  The quality of your post.
5.  The type of post: is it something to make people smile, something to make people think, something to acquire a lead; also is a text post of a photo post?
6.  What time were the posts performed and how did it interact with those fans in their daily life routines- eg: working hours, middle of the night, weekend night, time of Season be it Winter/Summer for Northern and Southern hemispheres etc.
7.  What is your protocol for engagement; eg- how often do you post, what are the main topics of each post and do they appeal to the broader audience of your fan base.
8.  Do your fans subscribe to your updates to be notified of each post?

In my opinion you'd need to go a lot further in your approach to proving fraud with that you have put here in the video.  As I shared in opening, I like the video and thanks for publishing it.

Cheers.

This type of behavior happens everywhere. It only seems problematic because facebook is super hot right now and growing so so rapidly in the ad space world. people will always try to "game" the system to make money.

We all don't shut off out computers and say never again because of spam do we ? Spam is a massive industry that generates insane amounts of money polluting our experience every day.

As for Facebook there are valid points you made in this video however to condemn the entire platform and brand it as "fraudulent" is just plain wrong. I speak from experience when I say Facebook advertising is extremely effective, when done properly, with the right tools. Using the native ad manager on the fb platform I can understand why you feel this way. Think about it like this, a mechanic working on a race car would have specialty tools for every nut and bolt he turned. Ever one of those bolts all torqued to spec down to the most granular metric. That mechanic defiantly would not use an adjustable wrench and a hammer to perform his precision work. Then when the engine blew up coming off the starting line condemn the parts he used in the engine. The same philosophy holds true here.

You need the right tools and the right strategy to effectively leverage Facebooks awesome potential. I have personally run campaigns on Facebook and delivered amazing results and when I say results I am referring to website traffic, leads, and sales! Yes sales actual $$$$

Is Facebook perfect ? Nope! is anything man made ? Nope ! Are there professionals that do this everyday that know how to leverage results on Facebook and other channels that can track back to real ROI ? Yep absolutely.

Your video was well made and you are an excellent speaker with a platform of follower to stand on your soap box. We all have those moments. I am not saying you did anything wrong but your theory is far from iron clad. You made some valid points but they are kinda 2011 -2012 for those of us that have been close to the industry and deal with the "gamers" every day.

The real value of Facebook is not likes and post engagement. It's knowing how to leverage Facebook to create a custom dynamic " in stream" experience for your target audience. The targeting available is amazing (it's not available on the native fb tool found at Facebook.com/advertising)

Fake Followers and Google+
I've actually experienced something like this on @Google+ - for some reason, several people (myself included) have seen a sudden and explosive increase in the rate at which they gained followers: dozens, hundreds, or even thousands of people followed us steadily each month for a long period of time.

I now have just shy of 15,000 followers, yet my engagement has only increased slightly and is still mostly people I connected with first (I had a few slightly-viral posts but I suspect that's because they managed to get on peoples' Explore streams.

Anecdotally, it seems like most of these people are similar to those in this video: located in developing countries, with minimal interaction except for prolific following.

Google+ very explicitly forbids advertisements and paid promotions, so the only conclusion I can reach is the one in this video, that bots and follow-farms are circling me for free to diversify their circles and avoid detection by @Google algorithms.

I might look in to this and cough up an article for @***** if I find anything interesting. I'm glad that Veritaserum got to the bottom of this and helped me get one step closer to cracking the puzzle.

(Funnily enough, I got here through a +1 by @Vic Gundotra who will hopefully take note that this might not just be a Facebook problem!)

Hi Veritasium! Your video was interesting. One thing I would like to add:

Deleting false likes is not that easy of a problem. First you have to determine if an account is false, which is easier said than done when you have 1 billion+ users. Use a machine learning algorithm that's too lenient, and the problem you have discovered appears. Use too strict of an algorithm, and you could risk deleting legitimate user accounts and thus angering legitimate users. 

Also, to some of the viewers: I don't think Facebook is paying click-farms to do this. From what the video theorizes, click-farms try to get around Facebook's click-farm detection software and hide their activity by just liking everything under the sun, thus making it harder for FB to detect what are spam likes and what aren't.

So unless you can find transactions between FB and click-farms, I doubt you will win any sort of court case for fraud :)

We had this problem with Facebook in late 2011/2012. After weeks of frustrating calls to Facebook customer service, we were able to solve the problem, and we have not had the problem since. I don't remember where it is in the Facebook settings, but (the customer service representative called it gating) we gated our page, meaning beyond just targeting our posts, we flat blocked our posts from showing in the countries we didn't want to promote to.

This has worked remarkably well for us.
We no longer get the junk likes that we used to get.

Watching your video, I think there is a big flaw in your reasoning. You make assumptions about personalities that are simply not true for all people. Coming from a North African country, I know people who have nothing on their hand but spend time on Facebook and will literally like anything they know. These recent likes were from people who were located mostly in Algeria (3 people), Indonesia (1 person), and Canada (1 person – but that one had his name written in Arabic script).

Here is Facebook's response to the above::

A Like that doesn't come from someone truly interested in connecting with a Page benefits no one. Real identity, for both users and brands on Facebook, is important to not only Facebook’s mission of helping the world share, but also the need for people and customers to authentically connect to the Pages they care about. When a Page and fan connect on Facebook, we want to ensure that connection involves a real person interested in hearing from a specific Page and engaging with that brand’s content. As such, we have recently increased our automated efforts to remove Likes on Pages that may have been gained by means that violate our Terms.
 
On average, less than 1% of Likes on any given Page will be removed, providing they and their affiliates have been abiding by our terms. These newly improved automated efforts will remove those Likes gained by malware, compromised accounts, deceived users, or purchased bulk Likes. While we have always had dedicated protections against each of these threats on Facebook, these improved systems have been specifically configured to identify and take action against suspicious Likes.
 
To be clear, we do not and have never permitted the purchase or sale of Facebook Likes as we only want people connecting to the Pages and brands with whom they have chosen to connect. Beyond the need to maintain authentic relationships on Facebook, these third-party vendors often attempt to use malware or other forms of deception to generate fraudulent Likes, which is harmful to all users and the internet as a whole.
 
These improvements to our site integrity systems benefit both users and brands alike. Users will continue to connect to the Pages and Profiles they authentically want to subscribe to, and Pages will have a more accurate measurement of fan count and demographics. This improvement will allow Pages to produce ever more relevant and interesting content, and brands will see an increase in the true engagement around their content.
 
To help protect yourself in the future, please be aware of suspicious links and visit www.facebook.com/hacked if you have any reason to believe that your account may be compromised. We also highly recommend that Page owners vet any business that offers marketing services to build your Facebook presence, to make sure that these companies are using only legitimate practices, which do not violate the Facebook Terms.
 
Facebook was built on the principle of real identity and we want this same authenticity to extend to Pages. We undoubtedly expect that this will be a positive change for anyone using Facebook, and we look forward to helping even more people share and connect with the friends and brands they care about.

As online activity increases, so do cultural expectations that the Internet can promote democracy and community through interactivity. But as online technologies progressively serve commercial ends, promises of communicative freedom may be endangered.
Threats to online privacy and autonomy are directly related to the unchecked commercialization of the Internet. Just as “loyalty clubs,” targeted advertising, and co-branded credit cards represent the consumer management strategies characterizing late 20th century capitalism, so does the use of “community” in its variant forms to connote that personalized mood in marketing techniques. Electronic traces left by online consumers allow companies to focus their efforts on consumer surveillance in the guise of “relationship marketing”. Increasingly, companies are using community sections of their web sites to obtain personal information about preferences, tastes, and desires which can supplement electronic trace information databases to create extensive personal electronic dossiers.

Like other commodities of the industrialized world, community can be exploited as a form of wealth that can be cultivated, mined, or sold like other capital commodities.

Will Dr. Muller get sued by Facebook for the title “Facebook Fraud”? Maybe not, as Facebook will probably want to avoid the Streisand effect... they will not want to draw attention to this video or the arguments it presents ... but ... 

The problem with  claiming that Facebook is doing something fraudulent is that Facebook is not  claiming that buying  "likes" provides genuine user engagement. The fact that Facebook openly advertises right on their website that they sell “likes” should be a clear sign that nobody should think that “likes” represent genuine or engaged followers.  

I believe that Dr. Muller does demonstrate that buying “likes” from Facebook is not a good value for someone who wants real user engagement. Buying likes decreases the chances that author's messages will get out to engaged readers. It is also true that we probably shouldn't judge the real popularity of a pop singer, gadget or political point of view from the number of likes on a Facebook page. 

Anyways, I hope that Dr. Muller does not get sued. I love what he brings to YouTube and science.

Thanks for pointing out what old school internet marketers have known for years: You can't monetize social traffic legitimately.
The only company that can monetize social traffic is Google - utilizing data from Google Plus. Why? Because Google's primary focus is search quality - and data from their social network helps them better target individuals and their "look alikes" with relevant ads. 
This is why I laugh when people bitch about Google Plus having no real users. Google doesn't care - it's just another way for them to improve your search results in other places. 
BTW- FB sucks for many reasons, not just this one. They seem to despise their advertisers and offer ZERO support. Google on the other hand, loves advertisers and assigns account reps to help you spend more money with them.
